abstract.para: Globally, human activities are altering environmental conditions through changes to disturbance regimes, climate, and primary productivity. Attempts to generalize changes in biodiversity in response to altered environmental conditions have had mixed success and the mechanisms that causes differences in responses are poorly understood. These contingent responses represent one of the largest obstacles to synthesis in community ecology and global change biology. Over the past decade, much progress has been made in resolving these ecological contingencies by shifting from a taxonomic perspective on community assembly and global change to a focus on functional traits. Functional traits are any morphological, physiological, or phenological characteristic of a species linked to fitness and have proven to be effective for understanding species interactions, biogeographic processes, and environmental change. Between 2008 and 2018, we measured plant height, specific leaf area, leaf size, chlorophyll content, stomatal conductance, leaf dry matter content, and leaf chemical composition (nitrogen, carbon, δ13C, δ15N) on 2689 individual plants from 141 species (not all traits on all individuals or species). These measurements were collected to capture intraspecific trait variation among the key habitat types on Niwot Ridge and to examine how species traits respond to global change in the ITEX experiment.

intellectualRights.para: This information is released under the Creative Commons license - Attribution - CC BY (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/). The consumer of these data (“Data User” herein) is required to cite it appropriately in any publication that results from its use. The Data User should realize that these data may be actively used by others for ongoing research and that coordination may be necessary to prevent duplicate publication. The Data User is urged to contact the authors of these data if any questions about methodology or results occur. Where appropriate, the Data User is encouraged to consider collaboration or co-authorship with the authors. The Data User should realize that misinterpretation of data may occur if used out of context of the original study. While substantial efforts are made to ensure the accuracy of data and associated documentation, complete accuracy of data sets cannot be guaranteed. All data are made available "as is." The Data User should be aware, however, that data are updated periodically and it is the responsibility of the Data User to check for new versions of the data. The data authors and the repository where these data were obtained shall not be liable for damages resulting from any use or misinterpretation of the data. Thank you.

description.para: See detailed methods included in entity “plant functional traits protocol”

project.title: LTER: Long-term research on the dynamics of high-elevation ecosystems -- a framework for understanding ecological responsiveness to climate change

attribute.attributeDefinition: Latin binomial
internal lab species abbreviations
Taxonomic family of collected species
Life form of collected species
Official USDA code for collected species
Replicate number of collected leaves
"Experiment" that species was sampled from (e.g. ITEX)

codeDefinition.definition: "Moving Up Hill" experiment on upper portion of ridge, approximate to D1
"International Tundra EXperiment" Experiment manipulating precipitation, nitrogen and temperature

attribute.attributeDefinition: Treatment within experiment (e.g. PNW - additional precipitation, additional nitrogen, warming)

codeDefinition.definition: Talus vegetation community (rocks) in MUH experiment
Control Precipitation, Control Nitrogen, Warming in ITEX plots
Control Precipitation, Added Nitrogen, Warmining in ITEX plots
Added Precipitation, Control Nitrogen, Warming in ITEX plots
Added Precipitation, Added Nitrogen, No Warming (Control) in ITEX plots
Control precipitaion, Added Nitrogen, No Warming (Control) in ITEX plots
Added Precipitation, Added Nitrogen, Warming in ITEX plots
Added Precipitation, Control Nitrogen, No Warming (Control) in ITEX plots

attribute.attributeDefinition: Unique string for each replicate of a collected species per experiment per treatment
Year specimen was collected
Latitude that replicate was collected at
Longitude that replicate was collected at
Volumetric Water Content % (VWC%) where species replicate was collected
Time that VWC% was collected during the day
Vegetative height - tallest photosynthetic leaf
Overall Height - Tallest point of entire plant, can be equivalent to Veg Height, or if flowers present, taller
Chlorophyll Content 1 - 1st estimate of leaf chlorophyll content for the collected plant
Chlorophyll Content 2 - 2nd estimate of leaf chlorophyll content for the collected plant
Chlorophyll Content 3 - 3rd estimate of leaf chlorophyll content for the collected plant
Chlorophyll Content Average - mean leaf chlorophyll content for the collected plant
Rate of water loss from leaves
Mass of leaf at full water content
Mass of dry leaf
Area of leaf at full water content
Leaf Dry Matter Content - mg dry mass over g full water content mass
Leaf Water Content - calculated from 1000-LDMC
Specific Leaf Area - area of leaf over mass of leaf
Leaf Mass Area - Mass of leaf per unit area
Delta 15 N, ratio of the stable isotopes 15N:14N in plant leaf
Delta 13C - ratio of the stable isotopes 13C:12C in plant leaf
Percent mass of N in dry leaf
Percent mass of C in dry leaf
Ratio of masses C and N in dry leaf

unit.name: percent
unit.description: ratio of two quantities as percent composition (1:100)

unit.name: micromolePerMeterSquared
unit.description: commonly used for integrated concentration of chemical constituents in natural water bodies

unit.name: micromolesPerSquareMeterPerSecond
unit.description: micromoles per square meter per second
